10.86.text:
I'm a writer and a journalist and,
once upon a time, an historian.

16.75.text:
A long time before I wrote books,
I used to work in the press,

21.74.text:
and specifically, in the street and
the fringe press.

25.77.text:
So I didn't work for
big newspapers or magazines,

29.25.text:
I worked for student newspapers and
music magazines.

34.79.text:
These were small operations that were,
you know, they were fringe,

41.83.text:
And I used to cover a lot of
political demonstrations.

45.45.text:
And I learned from years of doing
that, that you couldn't necessarily trust

51.22.text:
the reports of these demonstrations --
and sometimes of riots and so on --

56.98.text:
you couldn't trust the reports that
you would get in the mainstream press.

61.03.text:
And I came to understand that seeking the
truth about history was not just a matter

68.98.text:
of opening up whatever the newspaper
from that day or the following day said,

74.57.text: you had to dive a little deeper than that.

78.54.text:
You somehow had to get
yourself there into the event,

84.15.text:
even if it was 100 years
removed from where you were.

88.76.text:
When I was researching 'Leviathan', which
was the history of Sydney that I wrote,

94.26.text:
I was surprised to discover
that during the 1930s in Sydney,

98.80.text:
during a terrible, grim period  in our national 
history, which we call the Great Depression,

106.20.text:
when hundreds of thousands of people
were out of work,

110.24.text:
they were thrown out of
their homes, people used to starve to

113.21.text:
death in the streets of places
like Melbourne and Sydney.

117.70.text:
During that time there were thousands,
possibly tens of thousands of houses,

123.44.text: homes and apartments which were empty

126.28.text:
because men and women who were out of work
simply couldn't afford to pay the rent.

131.89.text:
A lot of these people, the men in
particular, had fought in the first world war,

136.06.text:
they were the people
we now venerate as the Anzacs.

140.40.text:
And because they'd had that
experience of going to war and

144.95.text:
facing an organised enemy 
and organising themselves to

149.50.text:
deal with that enemy,
that's what they did on the streets.

153.67.text:
They came together in groups like the
International Workers of the World, and

158.32.text:
I think there was one group called
the Unemployed Workers Movement or

162.10.text:
It was basically just a bunch of guys
who'd been mates in the army, who'd fallen

165.84.text:
on hard times and were trying 
to look after their families.

169.35.text:
One of the things they did was
they took over those houses,

171.65.text: they moved back in them. They squatted.

177.43.text:
The people who owned those properties
didn't want them squatting in there

179.98.text:
not paying rent and so
they sent in the police force.

183.53.text:
And the police force went in hard. 
Not just with fists and boots and billy clubs --

189.00.text:
although they used plenty
of those -- they went in with guns.

193.03.text:
And of course the people that they were 
attacking in those houses were ex-soldiers,

197.40.text:
and they'd had guns pointed at them 
and fired before, so they didn't go to water.

202.60.text:
They constructed barricades around 
this place, they ran up barbed wire.

207.07.text:
It was a terrible, violent
confrontation and

210.30.text:
a lot of people badly,
badly hurt out of it.

214.18.text:
If the only report, if the only history, 
if the only truth

220.80.text:
of that period you knew of was 
what you read in the paper,

226.21.text:
what you would read about
was a bunch of angry, evil,

231.80.text:
subversive communists who were
trying to ruin everything.

236.37.text:
Luckily, when I was doing my research,
just by chance,

239.63.text:
I came across the paper
archives of a lawyer.

244.42.text:
Strangely enough -- and it was strange
in those days -- a female lawyer,

247.91.text:
Christian Jolly-Smith,
I think her name was.

250.45.text: She took witness statements from them.

252.29.text:
Those witness statements were
the only alternative story

257.20.text:
to what happened in those riots. 
If I hadn't found those statements,

261.50.text:
if I hadn't basically accidentally tripped over them
 one day in the library in their paper form,

267.55.text:
the book that I told -- the history that I
told -- would have been a different history.

271.15.text: It would have been less accurate.

273.04.text:
Nowadays, people, they don't write in
journals, they don't write letters.

277.91.text:
Nowadays they make Facebook posts,
they tweet, they shoot video on their phone,

287.45.text:
All of that stuff, which we don't really
think about because

290.47.text:
it's like the air around us,
that's history.

293.06.text:
That is history in the same way
that Christian Jolly-Smith's

300.46.text:
In the same way that the notebooks of the
journalists who wrote about those stories,

306.11.text:
And that's where the truth lies and
I have seen it first hand.

312.53.text:
I covered a very, very violent confrontation
 in Melbourne

317.00.text:
about 10 years ago called the S11 Riots. 
Exactly the same thing as in the 1930s.

322.23.text:
If you followed the mainstream
media's reporting of those riots,

328.30.text:
all you would see was
a bunch of dreadlocked ferals

333.86.text:
with really unacceptable nose rings,
trying to rip the system apart.

339.24.text: Luckily those ferals all had phones, and

342.34.text:
they made their own reports
from within that riot.

346.13.text:
And what you got was this entirely,
almost counterfactual history.

352.23.text:
Like there was history in the pages of the
paper and on the screens of the nightly news,

357.79.text:
and here was another history
told by the people who lived it.

363.00.text:
That sort of stuff, that's the kind
of thing that we will find in digital archives

368.00.text: in the future, and that's why it's important to preserve it.

375.20.text:
I suppose you could ask why is
it important that somebody, or

379.17.text:
some institution like a library,
preserves this stuff.

382.78.text:
Why would a library want to keep a record
of tweets, and Facebook posts,

388.66.text:
and blogs, which aren't necessarily written
by the most important people in the land?

395.58.text:
Well, the fact is the history of any
land is the story of its people.

400.49.text:
And for the first time in human history
we actually have that story told

406.92.text: by the people, not by the institutions that won.

413.49.text:
History is written by winners, and
it's not necessarily the truth.

420.02.text:
Things that you see written in
textbooks that you think of as history,

426.16.text:
That's the stories that they like to
tell about how things came about.

432.16.text:
It's unfolding in Facebook posts,
as I said,

435.00.text:
you can see it in tweets,
see it in blog posts.

439.12.text:
And, you know what? Those things 
do seem to be archived.

441.04.text:
You can get onto Google, and
you can Google up anything.

445.60.text:
All of those posts that I was talking about -- 
the protesters in Melbourne at the S11 Riots --

451.00.text:
you could probably find a lot of those within 
a couple of seconds if you went looking.

457.09.text:
But only if the service that they
posted on was still with us.

461.58.text:
I used to have a blog on
a service called JournalSpace.

464.39.text:
I ran that blog for three years. It was
very popular, lots of people went there.

469.23.text:
JournalSpace collapsed,
the blog went away.

471.33.text: It's all gone, can't find it anymore.

478.01.text:
it's one of the most important
commercial institutions in the world.

482.87.text:
I think there's like 1.5 billion human
beings on it every single day.

488.61.text:
And they want to store --
they want to capture and store,

492.20.text:
every piece of data that you put on Facebook 
because that's their business model,

497.49.text:
So why would you need
a publicly funded library,

502.40.text:
in a university or just a state library,
why would you need them going

506.48.text:
through somewhere like
Facebook plucking off posts?

510.31.text:
Because we don't know that
Facebook's gonna be with us.

513.61.text:
Some companies last 100 years,
not many last much longer than that.

517.43.text:
Libraries -- state libraries, national libraries -- they 
archive memories for thousands of years, eventually.

524.70.text:
You go somewhere like
the British library and

527.36.text:
they are looking at the memory of that
nation going back over millennia.

532.48.text:
And that is why you need
to capture this stuff.
